utterances: A high level American delegation left Cuba yesterday with what they describe as a historic trade deal between the Communist country and a Navajo agribusiness.
The delegation signed a letter of intent for the Navajo Nation to sell Cuba beans, corn, wheat and other products.
The U.S.
trade embargo has exceptions for agricultural goods paid for in cash.
Congressman Tom Udall, who's Democrat from New Mexico, was among those traveling to Cuba.
The group didn't get to meet with Fidel Castro, who has always shown an interest in Native Americans.
They also didn't get to meet with acting President Raul Castro.
Fidel Castro ceded power to his younger brother when he was hospitalized last month.
This is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Melissa Block.
And I'm Michele Norris.
Today, the Pentagon announced that it has charged six detainees at Guantanamo Bay with murder in connection with the attacks of September 11th.
The men will become the first Guantanamo prisoners to face trial, and if they're convicted, they could receive the death penalty.
NPR's Guy Raz reports from the Pentagon.
For five years, the military has been building its case.
The Pentagon now says the case is ready.
Here's Air Force Brigadier General Thomas Hartman, the Defense Department's legal advisor to the military tribunal system.
These charges alleged a long term, highly sophisticated, organized plan by al-Qaida to attack the United States of America.
Hartman says Defense Department lawyers will now submit the charges to Susan Crawford, an outside convener appointed by the Pentagon who'll determine whether the charges are fit for trial.
Brig.
Gen.
HARTMAN: The chief prosecutor has requested that the charges be tried jointly and that they be referred as capital for each defendant.
It means that military lawyers will ask to try all six men together in one trial and to seek the death penalty.
Best known among those charged are Khalid Sheikh Mohammed and Ramzi bin al-Shibh.
Brig.
Gen.
HARTMAN: The charges alleged that Khalid Sheikh Mohammed was the mastermind of the 9/11 attacks.
By proposing the operational concept to a Osama bin Laden as early as 1996.
Last year, Mohammed boasted to a military tribunal at Guantanamo that he was behind the September 11 attacks.
All of the accused men have alleged they were tortured under U.S.
military custody.
In the case of Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, the CIA has admitted he was subjected to waterboarding - an interrogation technique that mimics the sensation of drowning.
But at the Pentagon today, General Hartman would not say whether evidence gathered under duress will be presented to the court.
